description.narrative: 1. Number of key sector policies reflecting Disaster Risk Management (DRM) interventions. 2. Percentage of national budget allocated to DRM activities 3. Average number of days taken to start assistance after onset of disasters.

comment.narrative: 1. DRM Policy approved 2. DRM Act review completed and submitted for legislation process 3. Small Grants Scheme pilot phase extended with additional resources from China Trilateral Cooperation. 4. DRM Communication Strategy implemented 5. Early Recovery Framework developed and implemented 6. Data collection completed in 14 districts for database creation.

1. DRM Policy approved by cabinet in February 2015 and launched in March 2015, currently under implementation 2. Technical review for the bill completed, pending stages are engagement of the parliamentary committee before consideration for enactment 3. Agreement with China and Government of Malawi signed, the programme to start implementation in January 2016. 4. DRM communication strategy is being implemented 5. A draft National Disaster Risk Recovery Framework has been developed 6. This milestone has not been realised, shifted to 2016.

description.narrative: Strengthened capacity of the Malawi Bureau of Standards to deliver business services and to achieve financial sustainability
independent political entity
policy, planning and administration

- Number of National Quality Policies (NQP), fast tracked and approved by Cabinet - Number of National Quality Strategies developed and approved for implementation - Number of standards accreditations granted to Malawi Bureau of Standards (MBS) by the International accreditation body - Number of Metrology Institutes constructed - Percentage increase in demand for Malawi Bureau of Standards services (standards, training services, testing and calibration) - Number of affirmative measures to increase level of organizational effectiveness of Malawi Bureau Standards - Number of SME able to comply with specific quality requirements in export markets.

comment.narrative: - 0 National Quality Policies (NQP), fast tracked and approved by Cabinet - 0 National Quality Strategies developed and approved for implementation - 0 standards accreditations granted to Malawi Bureau of Standards (MBS) by the International accreditation body - 0 Metrology Institutes constructed - 21 Percentage increase in demand for Malawi Bureau Standards services (standards, training services, testing and calibration) - 0 affirmative measures to increase level of organizational effectiveness of Malawi Bureau Standards - 0 Small and Medium Enterprises able to comply with specific quality requirements in export markets

- 1 National Quality Policy (NQP), fast tracked and approved by Cabinet - 1 National Quality Strategy developed and approved for implementation - Preparatory steps and initiatives for Malawi Bureau of Standards to move towards being granted accreditation standards in the pilot accreditation phase by the International accreditation body undertaken - Initial construction works of the Metrology Institute started - 21 Percentage increase in demand for Malawi Bureau of Standards services (standards, training services, testing and calibration) - 1 affirmative measure to increase level of organizational effectiveness of Malawi Bureau Standards - Recruitment of Small and Medium Enterprises to receive technical assistance to be able to comply with specific quality requirements in export markets

- 1 National Quality Policy (NQP), fast tracked and approved by Cabinet - 1 National Quality Strategy developed and approved for implementation - Under the pilot accreditation phase, both in-country and out-of-country specialised capacity building initiatives for the Malawi Bureau of Standards for ISO/IEC 17021 and ISO/IEC 17065 and ISO/IEC 17025 have been undertaken in 2015 including purchase of specialised equipment - Construction of the Metrology institute has started in November, 2015 - 21 Percentage increase in demand for Malawi Bureau of Standards (MBS) services (standards, training services, testing and calibration) - 1 affirmative measure to increase level of organizational effectiveness of Malawi Bureau Standards - Seven Small and Medium Enterprises have been recruited in Cohort 1 to get technical assistance so that they are able to comply with specific quality requirements in export markets. Assessment of Cohort 2 SMEs has been done pending finalisation of recruitment actual recruitment. Technical support will be provided on Food Safety Management system; and Quality Management System has been done.

description.narrative: 1. Number of planning instruments on climate change and planning documents produced at national level & district level. 2. Number of information and knowledge products on climate change produced . 3. Number of functional coordination mechanisms established and sustained. 4. Number of planning instruments for investment in climate change produced.

comment.narrative: 1. Climate change not mainstreamed in policies, development plans and programmes. 2. Data and knowledge on the impacts of climate change not accessible to the public. 3. Weak coordination mechanisms and implementation arrangements for climate change. 4. No plan for investment in climate change at national & district level.

1. 12 (8 National; 5 District) 2. 21 (7 climate information centres; 4 learning products for the primary and education sectors, 10 mass media programmes) 3. 5 coordination mechanisms fully functional. 4. 2 (roll out the climate change investment plan to investors and develop foundational work for development of a climate change fund)

1. 12 (Climate policy approved by cabinet committee; Meteorology Policy drafted; National Adaptation Plan road map drafted & stocktaking underway; M&E Framework for climate change, revised National Adaptation Programmes of Action, National Climate Change Response Framework and Nationally Appropriate Mitigation Actions launched, 4 district development plans mainstreamed climate change). 2. 18 (4 learning products for primary and secondary school sectors on climate change developed and used by the education sector; 4 climate information centres functional, 10 mass media and outreach programmes implemented). 3. 5 (technical, steering, Development Partners coordination group on climate change, GIS expert group and REDD Plus expert group established and fully functional). 4. 1

description.narrative: To strengthen the weather, climate and hydrological monitoring capabilities, early warning systems and available information for responding to extreme weather and planning adaptation to climate change in Malawi.

1. Capacity as per capacity assessment scorecard (Annex 12).
2. Domestic finance committed to DoDMA, DCCMS and DWR to monitor extreme weather and climate change.

comment.narrative:
1. Average CCA capacity scorecard rating of 72 across men and women (Annex 12).
2. Annual budget of USD allocated to DoDMA, DCCMS and DWR.

1. CCA capacity scorecard rating is increased to an average of 121 for both men and women (Annex 12).
2.20% increase in domestic financing committed to DoDMA, DCCMS and DWR to monitor extreme weather and climate change (including equipment operation and maintenance).

Considerable progress has been registered towards the attainment of objectives. Despite the fact that the actual implementation of the project started in 2014 with a lengthy procurement process, most of the hydrological and meteorological equipment has been purchased and delivered as well as installation in selected sites is on-going. Capacity building is also on track as a significant technical personnel from key institutions has received training thanks to the Department of Climate Change and Meteorological Services (DCCMS) and the Disaster Risk Management (DoDMA) who organised nine training courses ranging from 1 week to 24 months. A list of the afforded capacity building initiatives has been uploaded for referencing.
In relation to the set targets, the baseline and the two indicators, there was minimal quantifiable progress. This reporting period was mainly dedicated to preparatory activities.

description.narrative: The capacity of the Department of Climate Change and Meteorological Services (DCCMS) and Ministry of Irrigation, Agriculture and Water Development (MoIAWD) to monitor and forecast extreme weather and climate change enhanced.

1. Percentage of national coverage of climate monitoring network (fully operational).
2. Frequency and timeliness of climate-related data availability.

comment.narrative:
1. DCCMS – 15% national coverage of operational manual (15%) and automatic (0%) weather stations (Annex 6).
1. DWR – 52% national coverage of operational surface manual (85%) and automatic (19%) hydrological stations (Annex 6).
1. Number and type of operational stations:
Automatic weather stations: 6
Manual synoptic stations: 4
Manual river discharge and water level stations: 158
Rainfall logging stations actively transmitted through GPRS network: 0.
2. DCCMS:
i) 4 times daily between 5am-5pm for manual synoptic stations
ii) once a day for AWSs
iii) once a month for rainfall logging gauges.
2. DWR: daily to monthly basis.

1. DCCMS – 77% national coverage of operational manual (71%) and automatic (84%) weather stations (Annex 6).
1. DWR – 69% national coverage of operation surface manual (100%) and automatic (39%) hydrological stations (Annex 6).
1. Number and type of operational stations:
Automatic weather stations: 45
Manual synoptic stations: 22
Surface manual hydrological stations:
Manual river discharge and water level stations: 208
Rainfall logging stations actively transmitted through GPRS network: 53.
2. DCCMS: hourly for synoptic stations and daily for rainfall logging gauges.
2. DWR: 6 hourly and 2-4 hourly for flood prone areas.

There is considerable progress made towards the attainment of this outcome. The installation of the early warning infrastructure is underway as ten automated weather stations have been procured and installed in six out of seven districts (86% coverage of the project area which constitutes at least 9% of national coverage). Data from the AWS is being generated on an hourly basis. Hydrological equipment has been procured but not yet installed. Once installed, it is expected that it will contribute to at least 6% of national coverage. Modest progress has been registered that can be measured based on the indicators. During the reporting period in question the focus was on preparatory activities.

description.narrative: Hydro-meteorological and environmental information for early warnings and long-term development plans efficiently and effectively used.

1. Percentage of population with access to improved climate information and flood, drought and Mwera wind warnings (disaggregated by gender).
2. Policies, annual budgets and development plans that integrate climate information (type and level).

comment.narrative:
1. 10% of men and 10% women with access to improved climate information and flood, drought and Mwera wind warnings (to be confirmed during project inception).
Male: 628,620
Female: 663,136
2. Currently 0 policies and development plans.

1. 17% of men and 17% women with access to improved climate information and flood, drought and Mwera wind warnings (to be confirmed during project inception).
Male: 1,093,242
Female: 1,154,912
2. 7 District Development Plans and 1 National DRM Policy.

Access to early warning information was enabled through awareness creation exercises that were conducted at district level. 350 members of the Villages Civil Protection Committees (VCPC) received training on the benefits of early warning systems and the role that communities can play in disaster risk management.
The national disaster management frameworks have been enhanced: the National Disaster Management Policy has been approved by the Government of Malawi and dissemination at national level has been conducted. Preparations for district-level dissemination are underway.

description.narrative: The goal of the project is to secure the development and food security gains from the baseline programs by empowering communities to integrate climate risk considerations in the development policies, plans, projects and actions.
